abstracts.cdata!:
In 1998, the agricultural sector in
            Kazakhstan was at its lowest in 30 years. The World Bank and
            the Kazakh government launched the United States (U.S.) 15
            million dollars project as the first part of a larger
            program that focused on improving the country's policy
            and legal framework for rural finance, providing advice and
            training to newly emerging rural enterprises, and improving
            farmer's access to commercial financial services. The
            project helped bring about legal reforms as well, and
            allowed several thousand rural entrepreneurs to receive
            training in economics, marketing, and technical issues -
            easing the transition of restructured farms and associated
            enterprises to the new economy.

In 1998, the agricultural sector in
            Kazakhstan was at its lowest in 30 years. The World Bank and
            the Kazakh government launched the United States (U.S.) 15
            million dollars project as the first part of a larger

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings show satisfactory
            outcomes, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. Lessons highlight
            primarily the importance of project ownership, and effective
            management, actions which proved critical in accelerating
            the slow pace of implementation, by ensuring that qualified
            staff and consultants move the project towards successful
            development objectives. While the autonomy of the
            participating financial institutions (PFIs) in the selection
            of subprojects was conducive to a sound loan portfolio
            (based on a commercially driven criteria), this however, led
            indirectly to the high dominance of large borrowers, at an
            advantage over the smaller ones, in the ability to present
            adequate collateral, and economies of scale. Thus, in order
            to broaden the scale of rural lending, gaps in lending to
            smaller, underserved rural clients needs to be further
            analyzed; possibly, supporting microfinance, through
            non-bank financial institutions. Moreover, public
            information campaigns, technical assistance, and training
            should be further emphasized so as to enhance credit
            operational sustainability, and the capacity of PFIs, in
            order to lower the high risk, and costs perceived in rural
            lending. Similarly, although services to rural clients in
            the preparation of their business plans, training, and
            seminars were conducted free of charge, emphasis should
            focus on the need to determine, and establish a financing
            mechanism for these capacity building activities, to foster
            long-term sustainability.

repnme.cdata!:
Kazakhstan - Agricultural Post
            Privatization Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Post Privatization
            Assistance Project seeks to support the development of newly
            privatized farms and agro-enterprises in key agricultural
            areas of Kazakhstan and improve rural productivity and
            incomes. The program will include three phases. The first
            phase will focus on the legal framework, the institutions,
            and the procedures to support improved performance of rural
            enterprises and stimulate the flow of commercial bank
            financing to enterprises. The second phase will build on the
            first phase by expanding the coverage of the advisory
            services. The third phase will expand the program on a
            nation-wide basis. There are four components in this
            project. First, the rural advisory centers component will
            strengthen information for farm shareholders on shareholder
            rights, build local business support infrastructure to
            deliver advice and training on technical and commercial
            practices, and increase local capacity for the provision of
            advice. Second, the credit component will finance private
            farms and associated agri-businesses through participating
            financial institutions (PFIs). Third, the institutional
            development component will facilitate secured lending by
            developing procedures for using moveable property as
            collateral for bank lending; and creditor-led restructuring
            through capacity building in the PFI's on procedures
            for debt work-out, bankruptcy and liquidation. The fourth
            component will assist in the establishment of a Project
            Implementation Unit.
